title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
1. Motivating example


Research question: “To what extent do different teaching methods influence students’ ability to produce high-quality written texts?”
Method: Randomization and a CJ experiment. Specifically,




Randomly assign students to two different teaching method
Students will write preferably more than one text
We will assign judges to compare random pairs of texts
Judges will make more than one judgment (comparison)
Judges will produce a dichotomous outcome per comparison
\(\longrightarrow\) reflecting the relative quality of each text






Estimand: “On average, is there a difference in the ability to produce high-quality written texts between the two groups of students?”
Estimator: the Bradley-Terry-Luce (BTL) model [1, 2]
Estimates: BTL scores, or their transformations

Following current CJ practices

Thurstone: equal dispersion may not be applicable when researchers assess complex traits or heterogeneous stimuli, like texts!

Issue 2: Measurement and hypothesis tests
The BTL model serves as the measurement model for CJ [4–6, 9–13]
\(\longrightarrow\) The literature uses BTL scores (point estimates), or their transformations, to conduct additional analyses, such as:



Identify ‘misfit’ judges and stimuli [4–6]
Detect biases in judges’ ratings [4, 14]
Calculate correlations with other assessment methods [6, 13],
Test hypotheses related to the underlying trait of interest [13, 15–20]




A measurement model specifies how manifest variables contribute to the estimation of latent variables [21]

\(\longrightarrow\) introduce bias + reduce the precision of hypothesis tests [22, 23]
\(\longrightarrow\) diminish statistical power of tests

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
4. Extending Thurstone’s general form
So, the outcome’s ability to reflect the “true” differences between texts largely depends on the validity of the model’s assumptions [24].


Thus, we use Causal inference to address these issues and make relevant assumptions.
Specifically, we use SCMs and DAGs [25–28] to formally and graphically represent the assumed causal structure of the CJ system



Benefits:



They can represent causal structures using only five fundamental building blocks [28, 29]
They depict causal relationships in a non-parametric way [26]
They are conceptual models on which identification analysis and consistency rests.





Identification analysis determines whether an estimator can accurately compute an estimand based solely on its (causal) assumptions, regardless of random variability [30]
Consistency refers to the property of an estimator whose estimates converge to the “true” value of the estimand as the data size approaches infinity [21].
Identification is crucial because it is a necessary condition for ensuring consistent estimators. Without identification, consistency cannot be achieved, even with “infinite” and error-free data. Thus, deriving meaningful insights from finite data becomes impossible [30].

text:
4. Extending Thurstone’s general form
Specifically, we developed:


A conceptual-population model
A sample-comparison model



Benefits:



They clarify the interactions among all actors and processes involved in CJ experiments.
They shift the current comparative data analysis paradigm from passively accepting the BTL model assumptions to actively testing whether those assumptions fit the data under analysis.
They can strengthen measurement reliability and validity [31]
They can enhance the statistical accuracy of the hypotheses tests





more systematic and integrated way

section: 5. From SCM to a statistical model
text:
5. From SCM to a statistical model
Finally, with the structure in the previous SCM, we can derive a statistical model that addresses violations of the equal dispersions’ assumption.

Why?



Because SCMs encodes functional and probabilistic information, which we can replace with appropriate functions and probabilistic assumptions [26].
Because SCMs allows us to express the joint distribution of our complex CJ system as a product of simpler conditional probability distributions (CPDs), in the form of:





\[
\begin{aligned}
  P(O_{R}, & S, C, D_{R}, T_{IA}, X_{IA}, e_{IA}, T_{I}, X_{I}, e_{I}, B_{JK}, Z_{JK}, e_{JK}, B_{J}, Z_{J}, e_{J} ) & \\
  &= P(O_{R} \mid D_{R}, S, C) \cdot P(S) \cdot P(C) \cdot P(D_{R} \mid T_{IA}, B_{JK}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(T_{IA} \mid T_{I}, X_{IA}, e_{IA}) \cdot P(T_{I} \mid X_{I}, e_{I}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(B_{JK} \mid B_{J}, Z_{JK}, e_{JK}) \cdot P(B_{J} \mid Z_{J}, e_{J}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(X_{IA}) \cdot P(X_{I}) \cdot P(Z_{JK}) \cdot P(Z_{J}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(e_{IA}) \cdot P(e_{I}) \cdot P(e_{JK}) \cdot P(e_{J})  
\end{aligned}
\]


This re-expression is possible because the chain rule of probability and the Bayesian Network Factorization (BNF) property. For further details, see [26] and [28].

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.1 Discussion
We have proposed a model that:


Shifts the analysis paradigm from passively accepting to actively testing whether the assumptions fit the data [33]. Specifically, we have lifted the necessity of assuming:




Zero correlation between texts
Separate process for trait measurement and hypothesis testing
Equal dispersions between students or texts
No judgment biases
Dichotomous outcome
Need for removal of ‘misfit’ observations
Normal \(e_{IA}, e_{I}, e_{JK},e_{J}\) idiosyncrasies\(^{1}\)
Only two hierarchical components\(^{1}\)
Multidimensional traits\(^{1}\)






Stretching a bit the possibilities. Requires simulation analysis.

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.1 Discussion
We have proposed a model that:


Clarify interactions among actors involved in CJ experiments [33]:




Students and texts
Judges and judgments




Clarify two addional processes involved in CJ experiments [33]:




The sample mechanism is a generator of missing data. We can now use the missing data mechanisms MCAR, MAR, MNAR [34]
The comparison mechanism is a generator of missing data. We can now use the missing data mechanisms MCAR, MAR, MNAR [34]

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.2 Discussion: Limitations and challenges


No epistemological considerations for the connection between the quantitative and theoretical latent trait
Tested only in simulation scenarios (context dependent)
You need a deep knowledge of Causal inference
\(\longrightarrow\) e.g., what does it mean for predictor variables \(X_{IA}, X_{I}, Z_{JK}, Z_{J}\) to be part of the sufficient adjustment set?
You need knowledge of Probabilistic Programming Languages (PPL)
You need knowledge of Bayesian inference methods



a sufficient adjustment set of variables (potentially an empty set) refers to those that satisfy the backdoor criterion [28], that is, variables that block all non-causal paths without introducing new ones [25, 26, 35].
Naturally, the validity of causal claims now hinges on the assumption that these variables serve as a sufficient adjustment set, a property that cannot be guaranteed for any variable. Nevertheless, as [24] noted, drawing conclusions about the real world from observed data inevitably requires assumptions, and these requirements hold true for both observational and experimental data.

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.2 Discussion: Further research


Model testing trough simulation and power analysis (context dependent)
Package development
Apply the model to, for instance, replication studies:




“New” rules of thumb for sample sizes or number of comparisons
Are there benefits of adaptive comparative algorithms?
Effects of predictor variables on students, texts, judges, and judgments
Do repeated judgments bring benefits? (repeated measures design [36])
Are additive better than multiplicative judges’ biases (akin to discrimination in 2-PL IRT model)
How to work with random and non-random samples [37]
etc. etc. etc.
